dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Reed Hastings, the CEO of Netflix, just came out swinging against the new streaming competition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Reed Hastings, the C E O of Netflix, just came out swinging against the new streaming competition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, he called their offerings a detriment to consumers, right? Only good for advertisers, he says.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, he called their offerings a detriment to consumers, right? Only good for advertisers, he says.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The big dog of Internet TV acknowledged the new competitors as world-class consumer brands whose forthcoming services would be a boon to consumers and content creators alike.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he's not sweating it—even though he admits these new services will affect Netflix's growth because the shift to on-demand is so huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And he's not sweating it-even though he admits these new services will affect Netflix's growth because the shift to on-demand is so huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We dont anticipate that these new entrants will materially affect our growth because the transition from linear to on-demand entertainment is so massive and because of the differing nature of our content offerings, Hastings wrote Tuesday in an investor letter that accompanied Netflix's first quarter earnings release.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you look at the numbers—Netflix added almost 10 million subscribers in the U.S. last quarter alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you look at the numbers-Netflix added almost ten million subscribers in the U.S. last quarter alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Netflix reported record 9.6 million subscribers in the quarter that ended in March. Much of that growth7.86 million subscriberscame outside the U.S.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and revenue jumped 12% to $3.5 billion. But get this—they actually reported a net loss of 76 cents per share, which was worse than Wall Street expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and revenue jumped twelve percent to three point five dollars billion. But get this-they actually reported a net loss of seventy six cents per share, which was worse than Wall Street expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Revenue for the first quarter rose 22% to $4.5 billion, compared with a year earlier. Netflix reported a net income of 76 cents a share, exceeding the estimates of Wall Street analysts, who had forecast per-share earnings of 57 cents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oof, that's rough. And Disney+ didn't have a great start either, from what I remember.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof, that's rough. And Disney+ didn't have a great start either, from what I remember.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Netflix reported its earnings a week after Disney saw a favorable stock market bump following the unveiling of its Disney+ service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, Hastings thinks all these new services will struggle because, uh, people just don't want bad content. He says Netflix satisfies the demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, Hastings thinks all these new services will struggle because, uh, people just don't want bad content. He says Netflix satisfies the demand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He argued that theres ample appetite for great movies and TV shows, and Netflix only satisfies a portion of that demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he mentioned that Netflix is like 25% of all TV usage in the U.S.—that's wild. Still room to grow globally, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he mentioned that Netflix is like twenty five percent of all T V usage in the U.S.-that's wild. Still room to grow globally, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Netflix represents only about 10% of total TV usage in the U.S., its most mature market, Hastings noted, and there's more room to grow around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But he's not too worried about Disney and Apple—calls them just "a little bit more" competition in a crowded space.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he's not too worried about Disney and Apple-calls them just a little bit more competition in a crowded space.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theres a ton of competition out there, Hastings said in a recorded interview following the earnings release. Disney and apple add a little bit more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He did downplay Netflix's own originals a bit, didn't he? Like Umbrella Academy, which got 15 million views in its first month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He did downplay Netflix's own originals a bit, didn't he? Like Umbrella Academy, which got fifteen million views in its first month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the face of mounting competition, Hastings touted the strength of Netflix's original content. The Umbrella Academy, a series based on the comic book by Gerard Way and Gabriel Bá, which has been watched in 45 million households in its first four weeks on service, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then he also pointed out that Good Will Hunting—wait, that's not even a Netflix movie, is it? That's a mix-up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then he also pointed out that Good Will Hunting-wait, that's not even a Netflix movie, is it? That's a mix-up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Haha, definitely. I think he meant another title, but anyway—he also talked up their local content, like Nailed It! and that Korean show Crash Landing on You.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Haha, definitely. I think he meant another title, but anyway-he also talked up their local content, like Nailed It! and that Korean show Crash Landing on You.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Netflix looks to expand its subscriber base outside the U.S., Hastings touted the service's local program offerings. The service also premiered it first large scale Korean original series, Kingdom , in January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which he admitted was a flop in Korea and barely watched elsewhere. Kinda honest there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which he admitted was a flop in Korea and barely watched elsewhere. Kinda honest there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This period piece with zombies is our most successful season one show in Korea to date and has also been watched by millions of members outside of Korea, Hastings said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then Ted Sarandos jumped in saying their top 10 shows are actually non-originals. So their strategy's all about creating exclusive stories worldwide, even if some miss.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Ted Sarandos jumped in saying their top ten shows are actually non-originals. So their strategy's all about creating exclusive stories worldwide, even if some miss.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The top 10 show are all Netflix original brands, said Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a bold stance for sure, especially with everyone else jumping into streaming now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a bold stance for sure, especially with everyone else jumping into streaming now.

artist_script:
HostA: Reed Hastings, the CEO of Netflix, just came out swinging against the new streaming competition.
HostB: Oh yeah, he called their offerings a detriment to consumers, right? Only good for advertisers, he says.
HostA: Exactly. And he’s not sweating it—even though he admits these new services will affect Netflix’s growth because the shift to on-demand is so huge.
HostB: But then you look at the numbers—Netflix added almost 10 million subscribers in the U.S. last quarter alone.
HostA: Yeah, and revenue jumped 12% to $3.5 billion. But get this—they actually reported a net loss of 76 cents per share, which was worse than Wall Street expected.
HostB: Oof, that’s rough. And Disney+ didn’t have a great start either, from what I remember.
HostA: Right, Hastings thinks all these new services will struggle because, uh, people just don’t want bad content. He says Netflix satisfies the demand.
HostB: And he mentioned that Netflix is like 25% of all TV usage in the U.S.—that’s wild. Still room to grow globally, though.
HostA: But he’s not too worried about Disney and Apple—calls them just “a little bit more” competition in a crowded space.
HostB: He did downplay Netflix’s own originals a bit, didn’t he? Like Umbrella Academy, which got 15 million views in its first month.
HostA: Yeah, but then he also pointed out that Good Will Hunting—wait, that’s not even a Netflix movie, is it? That’s a mix-up.
HostB: Haha, definitely. I think he meant another title, but anyway—he also talked up their local content, like Nailed It! and that Korean show Crash Landing on You.
HostA: Which he admitted was a flop in Korea and barely watched elsewhere. Kinda honest there.
HostB: And then Ted Sarandos jumped in saying their top 10 shows are actually non-originals. So their strategy’s all about creating exclusive stories worldwide, even if some miss.
HostA: It’s a bold stance for sure, especially with everyone else jumping into streaming now.
